Questions under discussion
Asking a question: add the question onto an ongoing record of questions that need to be answered.


Discourse—at least involving assertions—always has the goal of answering some question (Roberts 2012).

There is always a Question Under Discussion (QUD).

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Summary

Speech acts: utterances that use a particular locution with a conventional meaning to achieve a certain social effect.
Conversational implicatures: inferences tied to particular speech acts, based on:

general principles of rational, cooperative communication (Grice 1975);
conventional meanings.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Where do we go next?

→ conventional meaning



First, we need to develop methods for observing and classifying inference types.
Then, we can focus on the conventional stuff:

study how it is encoded in linguistic expressions.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Defining inference
What is an inference?

A relation between expressions of a language.

\(E_{1} ↝ E_{2}\)

Typically, \(E_{2}\) is a declarative sentence.




Jo did some of the readings.  ↝ Jo didn’t do all of the readings.
Could you bring the dog inside?  ↝ There is a dog.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:

Speakers of the language!

Your friends.
Laboratory experiments.
Large crowd-sourced inference judgment studies.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
This class
Semantics is the study of conventional meaning in natural language.

Goal: give a ridiculously precise account of the inferences that linguistic expressions trigger.
If we can do this, then we have captured what these expressions mean\(_{NN}\).

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
A taxonomy of inference types

Some types of inference observable in natural language:

entailment
conversational implicature
presupposition
conventional implicature

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Entailment

A relationship between declarative sentences.
If \(S_{1}\) entails \(S_{2}\), then whenever \(S_{1}\) is true, \(S_{2}\) must be true.

Jo has at least three siblings.  ↝ Jo has at least two siblings.

Entailments are non-defeasible.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Non-defeasibility of entailments

#Jo has at least three siblings, {and, but} she doesn’t have at least two siblings.
# Jo is Bo’s sibling, {and, but} Jo and Bo aren’t siblings.
#No one came to class, {and, but} it’s not the case that Julian didn’t come to class.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Conversational implicature

Typically a relationship between utterances of declarative sentences.
If an utterance of \(S_{1}\) conversationally implicates \(S_{2}\), then the utterance means\(_{NN}\) \(S_{2}\).
Conversational implicatures are defeasible.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Defeasibility of conversational implicatures

Jo did some of the readings. In fact, she did all of them.
I want something with lots of caffeine. In fact, I want a matcha latte.
Context: Jo is writing a letter of rec. for Bo for the ling. instructor position.  Jo: Bo is very punctual. He has great handwriting. Last, but not least, he’d be a great ling. instructor!

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Presupposition

A relationship between an expression and a declarative sentence.
If \(E\) presupposes \(S\), then whenever an utterance of \(E\) is felicitous, \(S\) is true.

Jo stopped smoking.  ↝ Jo used to smoke.

Presuppositions are non-defeasible.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Non-defeasibility of presuppositions

#Jo stopped smoking, {and, but} she didn’t used to smoke.
#Jo loves that it’s raining, {and, but} it’s not raining.
#Bo failed the assignment, {and, but} there isn’t an assignment.
#Bo failed the assignment again, {and, but} he hasn’t failed it before.
